form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Schmitt (for himself and Mr. Scott of Florida) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To require each agency to repeal 3 existing regulations before issuing a new regulation, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Expediting Reform And Stopping Excess Regulations Act or the ERASER Act.

paragraph.text: The terms agency and rule have the meanings given those terms in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
The term major rule has the meaning given the term in section 804 of title 5, United States Code.
The term State means each of the several States, the District of Columbia, each territory or possession of the United States, and each federally recognized Indian tribe.

section.header: Repeal of regulations required before issuance of a new rule

subsection.text: An agency may not issue a rule unless the agency has repealed 3 or more rules described in subsection (c) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the rule.

paragraph.text: An agency may not issue a major rule unless—

subparagraph.text: the agency has repealed 3 or more rules described in subsection (c) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the major rule; and
the cost of the new major rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed.

paragraph.text: For any rule issued in accordance with paragraph (1), the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs of the Office of Management and Budget shall certify that the cost of the new major rule is equal to or less than the cost of the rules repealed.

subsection.text: A rule described in this subsection—

paragraph.text: does not include an interpretative rule, general statement of policy, or rule of agency organization, procedure, or practice; and
was issued through the notice and comment rulemaking process under section 553 of title 5, United States Code.

subsection.text: Any rule repealed under subsection (a) or (b) shall be published in the Federal Register.

paragraph.text: applies to any rule or major rule that imposes a cost or responsibility on a nongovernmental person or a State or local government; and
shall not apply to any rule or major rule that relates to the management, organization, or personnel of an agency or procurement by the agency.

section.header: Government Accountability Office study of rules
section.text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, and every 5 years thereafter, the Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct a study and submit to Congress a report that includes, as of the date on which the report is submitted—

paragraph.text: the number of rules that are in effect;
the number of major rules that are in effect; and
the total estimated economic cost imposed by the rules described in paragraphs (1) and (2).
